newsitem.title: USA: GOLF-MCCARRON IN THREE-WAY TIE FOR FREEPORT-MCDERMOTT LEAD.
newsitem.headline: GOLF-MCCARRON IN THREE-WAY TIE FOR FREEPORT-MCDERMOTT LEAD.

text.p: Scott McCarron began defence of his Freeport-McDermott Classic title exactly as he hoped, by grabbing a share of the first-round lead with a seven-under-par 65 on Thursday.
Sharing the top of the leaderboard after equalling McCarron's 65 on the English Turn Golf Club layout were Larry Rinker and David Toms.
Hideki Kase, a 14-year veteran of the Japanese tour playing his first year on the U.S. PGA Tour, was a stroke off the lead with a 66.

Australian star Greg Norman, a three-time runner-up here, was two strokes off the pace at 67 as he began his final tune-up for next week's Masters. Tied with Norman at 67 was qualifying school graduate Larry Silveira.

McCarron arrived at English Turn eager to get off to a good start in defence of his first PGA Tour title. He was also anxious to try out a new weapon -- Biggest Big Bertha, a 46-inch titanium driver he just acquired.
"It got me excited to come out here and play because I had a new toy," McCarron said.

McCarron is one of 20 players in the field using this event as a warm-up for the year's first major championship. That number was down from 22 after Seve Ballesteros withdrew Wednesday with a bad cold and Sam Torrance pulled out Thursday suffering from tendinitis.
McCarron earned the last 1996 Masters invitation when he beat Tommy Tolles and Tom Watson here. He secured his 1997 Masters berth by finishing 10th at Augusta last year.
Of the 20 players who broke 70 in the first round, however, only four are already in the Masters field.
The other 16 are vying for a victory Sunday that will bring a ticket to Augusta. Prominent among those hoping to win that final Masters spot are Payne Stewart and Lanny Wadkins, who each shot 69.
The players here seem to agree that this event makes for a fine Masters preparation.
"Of all the tournaments we could possibly play (ahead of the Masters), this is by far the best," said Billy Mayfair, who carded a 68.
"The greens here are fast and in perfect condition," said Norman, who is hoping to erase the memory of his staggering final-round collapse at Augusta last year.
"It's also a second shot golf course that requires precise positioning with your irons, which are the skills you need for Augusta," Norman said.
Norman was encouraged by improved putting Thursday with his score 12 strokes better than his final round last week at the Players Championship.
"I still need to do a little more work, but last week I made none, today I made five, and maybe next week I'll make all the putts," Norman said.
